gamut.spectrum package

Submodules

gamut.spectrum.Spectrum module

class gamut.spectrum.Spectrum.Spectrum(counts, *args, **kargs)[source]

Bases: ndarray

Spetrum is the most basic object of GAMUT. It is used to store data of a gamma spectrum. It is a view of 1-d numpy.ndarray.

Initialize the spectrum object with the given counts and optional parameters.

Parameters:

  • counts – The channel-wise counts of the spectrum

  • label – Optional, the name or label of the spectrum

  • regions – Optional, the list of ROIs of the spectrum

  • attrs – Optional, the dictionary of trivial attributes of the spectrum

  • ergcal – Optional, the energy calibration of the spectrum

  • FWHMcal – Optional, the FWHM calibration of the spectrum

property label: str

The name or label of the spectrum.

property regions: list[Region]

The list of ROIs in the spectrum.

property attrs: dict

The dictionary of trivial attributes of the spectrum.

property ergcal: Calibration

The energy calibration of the spectrum.

property FWHMcal: Calibration

The FWHM calibration of the spectrum.

property length: int

The length of the spectrum.

property indexes: ndarray

The indexes of the spectrum.

property energies: ndarray

The energies of the spectrum. Available only when the spectrum is calibrated.

property counts: ndarray

The channel-wise counts of the spectrum.

property nregions: int

The number of regions in the spectrum.

property npeaks: int

The number of peaks in the spectrum.

property peaks

The list of peaks in the spectrum. It retuns a copy of the peaks.

from_GammaVision(filename: str)[source]

Import the spectrum from a GammaVision file.

Parameters:

filename – The path to the GammaVision file.

from_excel(filename: str, counts_column: str, energy_column: str | None = None)[source]

Import the spectrum from columns of excel files.

Parameters:

  • filename – The path to the excel file.

  • counts_column – The name of the column containing the counts.

  • energy_column – The name of the column containing the energies.

static export_to_xml(spectrum, filepath: str | Path, data: dict[str, bool] = {'FWHMcal': True, 'FWHMcal.verbose': False, 'ergcal': True, 'ergcal.verbose': False, 'regions': True, 'regions.peaks': True, 'regions.peaks.verbose': False, 'regions.verbose': False}) → None[source]

Export the report to a xml file.

Parameters:

  • spectrum – Spectrum object to be exported.

  • filename – Path to the file where the spectrum will be saved.

  • data – Dictionary indicating which data will be included in the report.

gamut.spectrum.SpectrumPlotter module

class gamut.spectrum.SpectrumPlotter.SpectrumPlotter[source]

Bases: object

plot(ax: Axes | None = None, chinese_label: bool = False, *args, **kargs) → Axes[source]

Plot the spectrum.

Parameters:

  • ax – The axes to plot on.

  • chinese_label – Whether to use Chinese labels.

  • args – Other arguments to pass to plt.plot

  • kargs – Other keyword arguments to pass to plt.plot

Returns:

The axes object.

plot_regions(ax: Axes | None = None, chinese_label: bool = False, *args, **kargs) → Axes[source]

Plot regions of the spectrum, with peaks marked as stars.

Parameters:

  • ax – The axes to plot on.

  • chinese_label – Whether to use Chinese labels.

  • args – Other arguments to pass to plt.plot

  • kargs – Other keyword arguments to pass to plt.plot

Returns:

The axes object.

plot_peaks(min_fitness: float | None = None, axes: Axes | None = None, chinese_label: bool = False, baseline: ndarray | None = None, plot_baseline: bool = True, plot_fitted: bool = True, *args, **kargs) → Axes[source]

Plot detailed fitted peaks in regions of the spectrum. Baseline is optional to reconstruct the unstripped spectrum.

Parameters:

  • min_fitness – The minimum fitness of the region to be fitted.

  • axes – The axes to plot on.

  • chinese_label – Whether to use Chinese labels.

  • baseline – The baseline to be fitted.

  • plot_baseline – Whether to plot the baseline.

  • plot_fitted – Whether to plot the fitted spectrum.

  • args – Other arguments to pass to plt.plot

  • kargs – Other keyword arguments to pass to plt.plot

Returns:

The axes object.
